page.title: 03GEOLOGY OF BRAILES
page.content: The valley in which the village of Brailes lies, and the lower slopes of Brailes Hill, are formed of yellow and buff silty clay known as the Middle Lias silts.The Marlstone Rock Bed above the silts is very thin and on top of that, the higher slopes of the hill are formed of Upper Lias Clay. Many years ago this was dug for making bricks and tiles in the local brickworks. The hill cap is formed of ferruginous and calcareous sandstone called Northampton Sands.Round the topmost clump of trees,named Highwall Spinney, is an area of pale sandstone and Chipping Norton limestone.Along the base of the Northampton Sands is a series of springs which yield small supplies of water to individual farms and houses on the hillside.
